Șoseaua Jellicoe, Melina MarchettaAceastă carte este exact genul care te poate bulversa. Cu o descriere mai degrabă interesantă, mi-am dorit să o citesc și să rezolv misterul. Până pe la jumătate, n-am înțeles absolut nimic, iar dacă eram întrebată despre cum este lectura, spuneam doar că nu știu. Pentru că nu știam. Pur și simplu nu empatizam cu personajul și nu îmi dădeam seama încotro duce acțiunea.Povestea este despre Taylor, care este părăsită de mama sa pe șoseaua Jellicoe pe când avea doar unsprezece ani. Acum, la șaptesprezece, ea este responsabilă cu căminele de la Școala Jellicoe. De când se știe, are aceste vise ciudate, cu un băiat trist care stă într-un copac și care îi vorbește. Dar Taylor este destul de pragmatică și nu își lasă sentimentele la vedere, căci pentru ea ar fi un punct vulnerabil. Printre atribuțiile sale se află și menținerea teritoriului comunității din care face parte. Dintotdeauna a existat un război între școală, Orășei și Cadeți, fiecare parte dorind să-și protejeze teritoriul și să nu-i lase pe ceilalți să depășească granițele. Practic, toată povestea se leagă de această luptă, ceea ce mi-a fost destul de neclar. De ce ar scrie cineva o carte doar cu scopul de a arăta cum se războiesc niște adolescenți pentru niște poteci, copaci, râuri și alte asemenea? Dar apoi mai e și Hannah, un fel de mentor al lui Taylor, care locuiește în afara limitelor școlii, și care dispare în mod misterios, lăsând în urma ei un manuscris format din pagini amestecate, fără început și fără sfârșit. Acolo, ea vorbește despre o tragedie care a adus împreună cinci tineri. Totul pare ireal, nelalocul lui, căci fiecare indiciu duce către niște vieți care au existat cândva. Și, cu toate că nu vrea să se arate atașată de femeie, Taylor se simte din nou părăsită și nu încetează din a crede că i s-a întâmplat ceva lui Hannah.Reîntâlnirea cu Jonah Griggs, conducătorul Cadeților, o trimite pe Taylor înapoi în trecut, când cei doi au avut ceva în comun. Cu toate luptele lor pentru putere, nu pot nega că între ei există o văpaie. Am crezut că nu voi regăsi deloc dragostea în această carte, dar a existat în fiecare filă, sub toate formele ei. Ascunsă, căci iubirea e exact ca o nestemată. Și abia atunci când răsare, poți să respiri ușurat .Povestea a fost amețitoare, m-a făcut să mă încrunt, dar mi-a smuls și zâmbete. This is how you write a book. Hands down. I feel overwhelmed. I’m sad and I’m happy. You know, after reading a book you sometimes wonder how it would’ve been different if something changed about it, or how you would have wanted it to be some other way. This is the story where I want nothing to change. I love it how it is. It’s a story I’ll never forget.When I started Jellicoe Road, it took me some time to get into the story. I was confused as to how the two stories were supposed to be related and it was mainly because I couldn’t read more than a few pages at a time. When I finally got into the story, I admit I had predicted some things but I don’t mind it at all because it felt like the author wanted me to know. Taylor had it figured out herself so it’s not as if she was some dumb, stubborn, moody protagonist. She did get on my nerves in the beginning. She pushed everyone away and had so many issues that I got angry on her at times but later, reading the story, I sat there feeling choked up with my eyes burning and trying to push back the tears because I was sitting around everyone reading the book and I didn’t want to draw attention to myself. Marchetta has such a beautiful way of writing a story. She is really a great author and I’m kinda shocked that it took me so long to discover her work. I felt everything that Taylor felt. It’s been sometime since I fell in love with the characters of a story. I adore everyone in this book. I love Webb, Narnie, Tate, Fitz, Jude, Taylor, Jonah, Raf, Chaz, Ben, and almost everyone else. Marchetta so beautifully manages to make every character she has mentioned in the story involved. Everyone is part of the story, unlike some authors who manage to bring up so many unimportant characters that are not even related to the story and are just made up and just as suddenly, simply gone. I can’t even imagine how it would’ve been for kids who became orphans in just a matter of minutes and how it became the turning event in all their lives. How that one accident took everything away from them and then gave them so much in return. To even imagine what Narnie, Webb or Tate had to go through, is like feeling someone crushing something inside me. I get very emotional when any character’s parent dies and in this story there is so much loss that I kept staring at a wall, blocking my thoughts listening to other’s talk around me, so that I don’t lose it infront of everyone. Every character in this story is significant and everyone is so different and each one of them has to face their own personal demons but when they are together, they simply enjoy each other’s company. And to have a relationship like those guys is something that can make anyone envious. Figuring out everything with Taylor and being with her on the roller-coaster ride of emotions was such a journey! I love her character. Truly. She had been through so much and she tried so hard to never get attached to anyone and tried so hard to hide emotions when she could hardly keep them in. She was so strong and even in her vulnerability, she did not fail to amaze me. She was broken but she held herself for everyone. I loved her relationship with Raf and Ben and Chaz and most importantly Jonah. Jonah and Taylor were perfect for each other and it’s been so long since I’ve loved two characters in a relationship together. Jonah knew how to act around her when she lost her temper. He didn’t sugar-coat anything and he was on her face and wasn’t scared of her like the others. He knew how to deal with her mood tantrums and in the same way Taylor was everything for him. She gave him a reason to survive and she understood him just as he understood her. *squeeeeeeeee* I feel giddy thinking about them together. Gee, I feel so girly. Anyways, if I start writing about the things that made me depressed or that I particularly liked, I would end up writing everything. So, I’m going to keep it short and say that it’s a story to know, a story to read, a story to remember, and a story that will make you cry with sadness as well as happiness. I loved the pacing, I loved how there were two stories and how those two stories were related together. I think I deserve a pat on the back for not bawling my eyes out and believe me there were moments when I would have just done that if not for the company. I have an urge to re-read it all over again and I will. Soon. The starting was shaky and the war seemed to be a frivolous issue but when I was in high school I remember having the same kind of rivalry with girls and guys of other schools for no reason..only cause it was. So, I guess I can see that. Also, Jesse knowing about where the tunnel was to save her life and Chloe's seemed unlikely. But overall, this book left an impression.

This took me about 3-to-4 hours to read in total. I started before falling asleep and then I picked it up the next morning and could not put it down until I was finished. Now, that may sound strange when I tell you that I almost didn't finish it after reading the first few chapters. I think I was just too tired to deal with the way it was written. It's sort of a puzzle at first, trying to decipher what was past, what was present, what was dream and what was reality because the author set it up in such a way that everything becomes a slow reveal. I love a good mystery and while this is not a mystery in the traditional sense of "whodunit", it is a very mysterious book, full of hints and teases. However, I found those hints to be very tiresome at first. So, I put the book down for the night and picked it up the next morning, thumbing through to see if I'd like what was to come, looking for answers to some of the questions that wouldn't leave me alone. I skimmed and found myself sucked into the story so that I would skim a little further still, before fully becoming invested. Finally, after much skimming, I went back and started over, reading passages that I'd missed through my first read, until finally I finished the entire book.I don't normally read books that way but I think the skimming really helped me stick with this book and I am so glad I did. I almost took it back to the library, unfinished! It's a very moving story, though like I said a little confusing at first. I couldn't figure out what this whole Townie vs Cadet vs "Us" thing was. Just stick with it, it'll all make sense as you go along. For better reviews of the actual book, read some others around here because this isn't so much as a review as a telling of how pulled in I was by the book once I gave it a chance. Let me leave you with the opener, though. One of the most tragic and sucked-me-right-in openers I've ever read."My father took one hundred and thirty two minutes to die.I counted.It happened on the Jellicoe Road. The prettiest road I’d ever seen, where trees made breezy canopies like a tunnel to Shangri-La. We were going to the ocean, hundreds of kilometres away, because I wanted to see the ocean and my father said that it was about time the four of us made that journey. I remember asking, “What’s the difference between a trip and a journey?” and my father said, “Narnie, my love, when we get there, you’ll understand,” and that was the last thing he ever said.We heard her almost straight away. In the other car, wedged into ours so deep that you couldn’t tell where one began and the other ended. She told us her name was Tate and then she squeezed through the glass and the steel and climbed over her own dead – just to be with Webb and me; to give us her hand so we could clutch it with all our might. And then a kid called Fitz came riding by on a stolen bike and saved our lives.Someone asked us later, “Didn’t you wonder why no one came across you sooner?”Did I wonder?When you see your parents zipped up in black body bags on the Jellicoe Road like they’re some kind of garbage, don’t you know?Wonder dies."

But even if I didn't have reason number two, I would have still continued reading because Melina Marchetta created magic with her writing and just the flow of words had me wanting to turn the pages. The confusing shift between past and present was difficult to understand at first, but once I got the connection between the two, it became incredible. Un lugar al que todos pertenecerían y anhelarían estar. Un lugar en el camino de Jellicoe

 Taylor Markham tenía once años de edad cuando fue abandonada por su madre en el camino de Jellicoe. Ahora, con diecisiete años de edad, Taylor no sólo es la nueva líder de su dormitorio del internado, sino que también va a descubrir muchos secretos sobre su vida antes de llegar a Jellicoe, sobre todo después de la persona que la cuidaba, Hannah, desaparece de repente de la escuela sin decirle nada a Taylor. En medio de todo eso Taylor se encuentra con su antiguo novio, Jonah Griggs y sospecha que Jonah sabe más acerca de ella de lo que ella misma sabe. Ahora, Taylor debe descubrir la verdad sobre el abandono de su madre y el paradero de Hannah. Y lo que va a descubrir sobre su verdadero pasado cambiará su vida para siempre.Melina Marchetta crea una historia misteriosa que rodea el pasado de Taylor y como afecta su estado actual. En realidad en el principio, hay muchas piezas de información que son como un rompecabezas que tienes que ir encajando mientras vas leyendo. Por cada capitulo que leía era como "¿y a donde se supone que me lleva esto? ¿que paso con Hannah? ¿y que hay de la mama de Taylor? ¿y quien se supone que ese niño?" Me gustó el personaje de Taylor Markham aunque hubo momentos en que su actitud agresiva hacia los demás me molestó, puedo identificarme con ella en la forma en que le resulta difícil confiar en las personas después de que su madre la abandonó y que Hannah, la persona más cercana que tenía a una familia, de pronto se fue. También me gustó mucho la relación de Taylor con Jonah Griggs, Raffaela, Ben, y Chaz Santagelo ya que fueron grandes amigos para ella, y sobre todo me encantó la forma en que estos personajes trataron de ayudar a Taylor con sus problemas de confianza y como le enseñaron el verdadero significado de la amistad. Ame la forma en que Melina Marchetta localizo esta historia en Australia. La manera en que describe los lugares, por ejemplo: el camino de Jellicoe y el Árbol de Las Plegarias. Los fragmentos del manuscrito de Hannah, donde se cuentan las historias de Webb, Narnie, Tate, Fitz y Jude fueron mis partes favoritas del libro. Eran desgarradoras y conmovedoras, aunque en el principio no las entendía. Cuando todo empezó a tener sentido descubrí lo muy importante que eran esos fragmentos en la historia. Melina Marchetta es definitivamente una de mis escritoras favoritas. Y espero con ansias leer otro de sus libros.

If I had been able to understand the story from page one I would be giving it five stars. I loved it from about page 175 or so on. I hadn't read any reviews or summaries before I started, I just bought it because it was on sale and had a pretty cover. Sometimes I do that. Sometimes I find treasure. Sometimes I find trash. I'm willing to take the risk. Having said that, I thought the book was set in the future and was somewhat dystopic when I first began. It wasn't.Taylor, our narrator attends a boarding school and her classmates, "Townies" and "Cadets" participate in some sort of war. I thought this was an actual war and that there would be dire, possibly even fatal, consequences to these skirmishes. When I finally realized the war was just a game these kids played for six weeks of the year the rest of the story fell into place. I was able to understand what was going on, get to know the characters and realize that the reason the story kept changing, and I often felt lost, was that sprinkled throughout Taylor's story is the story of five other kids in the past. Ah ha!Taylor was abandoned by her mother at the tender age of 11. She has always kept others at arm's length, been hesitant to show emotion and comes across as a bit of a bad ass. At 14 she attempts to run away from the school and find her mom. Her path and a young boy's, Jonah, meet up and their journey ends in what she feels is his betrayal. He calls home for someone to come and get them just before they reach where she thinks she needs to search. She doesn't know the true reasons he makes the call and when she and Jonah encounter each other three years later she has a hard time dealing with it. The story is about the loss of, and eventual reunion of, family. About establishing roots and knowing the history those that came before you. There's also romance, and praise the Lord, hallelujah, it's a healthy romance between teenagers. Marchetta writes these teens as difficult, angst-y, rude, snarky and touchy. In other words just like the teenagers I live with. They are not manipulative, overbearing, physically or mentally abusive and they allow each other to be who they are without attempts to change that or rule over each other's lives.I enjoyed the last part of the book so much(once I figured it out) that I may need to go back and reread. If I do I will probably end up giving it five stars.

Seevastu "Jellicoe Road" jättis mulle üllatavalt sügava mulje.Ema hülgas Taylor Markhami, kui ta oli 11-aastane ning sellest ajast saadik on tüdruk õppinud internaatkoolis, kus ka paljud teised lapsed on probleemsed. Näiteks on seal mitu süütajat. Neiu üritas ühe korra ka minema joosta, kuid toodi tagasi. Igal aastal tulevad kooli lähistele telkima Kadetid ning toimuvad sõjamängud territooriumi üle. Taylor valitakse oma kooli esindama, kuid tal on ka teisi muresid. Üks vähestest täiskasvanutest, keda ta usaldab, on kadunud ning neiu ihkab teda iga hinna eest leida. Vastuseid otsides leiab tüdruk aga vihjeid oma enda mineviku kohta.Mulle meeldis raamatu müsteerium, mis küll poole pealt juba ilusti välja joonistus, kuigi Taylor ise oleks võinud ka asjast veidi varem aru saada. Selliseid saladusi ei oleks tohtinud tema eest õieti hoidagi. Samuti tundusid põnevad sõjamängud, mis küll veidi muu loo kõrval tahaplaanile jäid. Veidi nooremale lugejaskonnale saaks juba luuramiste ja vallutuste põhjal väga nauditava loo. Territooriumitest rääkimise juurde oleks muidugi ilusti passinud ka kaart. Ükskõik, kui probleemne ja murtud oli peategelane, siis tegelikult oli lugu positiivse alatooniga ning keskendus leinale, lootusele, sõprusele ning sihikindlusele. Raamatut lugedes tajusin, kuidas halvast saab sündida hea. Lõpu poole liikudes tuli küll rohkelt kurbust ja poetasin isegi paar pisarat, isegi mitte nukrusest, vaid lihtsalt olin Taylori loost liigutatud.

I want to read this for the first time, again. The first chunk of the book introduces Taylor. She pushes people away, is more interested in being alone than not and, in fact, rarely pays attention to anyone who happens to be around. Sound like it might be boring to read? It kinda was. It’s disjointed with little dialogue and the protagonist doesn’t go out of her way to endear herself to the reader. But it’s all in such a way that made me wonder why.And then it picks up. When a leadership position falls into her lap, Taylor takes it on grudgingly. She doesn’t rely on anyone and definitely doesn’t want to be relied upon, but the alternative means falling under someone else’s rule. The stories that she’s never understood from her past confront her more and more as she’s forced to work with others. It’s a little heartbreaking when Taylor doesn’t seem to notice that others need her as much as she needs them. During all the time that she’s thought she never had family, it’s revealed to have been quietly and steadily building itself up around her. It snuck up on me. Suddenly I was enmeshed in the lives of these characters and I was glad that they belonged to me for a little while. The story doesn’t rush in revealing itself and the confusion becomes alluring. It’s almost morbidly fascinating how one tragedy can snowball and affect so many lives. I love the idea that you create your own family, and that people can belong to each other in so many ways and for so many reasons. Like I said, I’m a little disappointed that I won’t get to experience reading this for the first time again.And, bonus, I have a new song to add to my musical rotation. I don’t know if I would have loved its ‘80s goodness without the book or if the book has imprinted itself onto the song in my head, but I’m digging The Whole Of The Moon by The Waterboys.

This book is one of those books that surprise you. Well, it surprised me anyway. I'd heard that it was good but that it wasn't everyone's favorite of books. But I LOVED this book. My one critique was that the beginning was hard to follow. Marchetta jumps right into the story without explaining much of the backstory or who the characters are. So it takes a few chapters to get into the groove of the story. But as you read, you learn not only how she has formatted the story, but begin to unravel the mystery that is the backstory of the characters. She drops you into the middle because she wants you to discover the beginning. The way she weaved the story together was, in my opinion, brilliant. It made a contemporary story into a mystery. And I really enjoyed how the once sworn enemies became best friends.I will say that I felt the Territory War was a bit underplayed. It was such a giant priority in the beginning of the novel, and just disintegrated. I expected to have more fights with her other leaders, more "battles" for territory, and more war games between the Townies and Cadets. I really loved that everyone became best friends, but the huge war that was so important at the start of the book just wasn't a big deal shortly after.All in all, a wonderful book. I'm glad I pushed past the first few chapters so I could really understand and love this book!

Rounded up from 4.5. I didn't realize I signed up for an emotional read until I reached two-thirds of the book. The premise tackles about territory wars between three factions: the Townies, the Cadets, and Jellicoe High School's underground community. But more than that, the novel explores the back stories of the factions' leaders and the adults around them, thus, unfolding two tragic stories about love, friendship and family. The fight for territories was intriguing, until that storyline got dumped midway (because it has, unfortunately, served its purpose) to focus on Taylor's quest of finding her mother and her guardian, Hannah. It took me a while to catch up with the characters, but it wasn't hard to fall in love with them as soon I got to know them. I love the sexual tension between Taylor and Jonah early in the story, but it fizzled out midway because it got a bit mushy for me at some parts. I also love the characterization, especially on Taylor and Jonah. They are two broken, vulnerable teenagers hiding behind their tough-looking persona, and I love how the author explored and explained their back stories. They are not your ordinary strong-willed characters. There were dull, predictable moments, particularly on the latter part of the story, but the epilogue stabbed me in the heart and left me aching for the characters involved.

I absolutely hated this book...and then I loved it. The first half was tedious, boring and very put-downable. I didn't like the author's writing style. It kept bouncing back and forth between the story of a girl living at a boarding school and a story of five friends. It was horribly confusing as it wasn't explained until later on that the story of the five friends happened in the past and was being read from a manuscript in the present. The worst part of the first half has to be the ongoing war between the kids in the boarding school, the kids from town and the cadet school. They fought over paths, fields, tree houses, etc., and these weren't arguments, they were beating each other up and taking hostages......and once you got into the second half it all started making sense. Every person mentioned in the first half became important in the second half. Everything and everyone was connected. I even cried at the end and that NEVER happens, well pretty much never.This is the story of family, and the lack of family, and the lengths people will go to for their family. It's about the beginnings of friendships that last a lifetime. It's about secrets. It's one of the best young-adult coming of age stories I have read.

I'm tempted to rate this book higher and maybe I will after a reread. I can see why it won all of the awards and is so well reviewed, but for the first half of the book I was very confused. There are two storylines (an italicized manuscript and the main character Taylor's POV), alternating between past and present, lots of characters and I got frustrated trying to piece it together. But then I read reviews and they all said the same thing about being lost for the first 150 pages so I kept going. I'm SO glad I did. Everything fit together beautifully in the end and all I could think was "wow." The story is well written, multi-layered and original. (I went into it only having read the blurb and knowing it was YA fiction, and I think that's the way to go). It's a mysterious story about friendship, abandonment, guilt, grief and forgiveness. Taylor Markham lives in a boarding school though she spends quite a lot of time with Hannah, a woman who lives in a large house nearby. When she was seven, Taylor was abandoned by her mother, and four years ago, Taylor tried to head for Sydney to find her; but Jonah, who was accompanying her, caused their trip to be prematurely stopped when he made a phone call and the Brigadier came to collect them. Taylor has never forgiven him.During the unfolding of Taylor's story we are also given snippets of the story of 5 children who lived there 20 years ago, by way of a manuscript that Hannah is writing, and we are gradually given clues to help us see who they are now and what happened to them. Those snippets aren't written in chronological order, so the reader must be alert. Their story together began with a car crash that killed parents, so they also have abandonment and misery to contend with.The whole is told within an elaborate "war" that Taylor's school, and the Cadets and the Townies all follow for territory, and within a heart-warming (and sometimes heart-breaking) story about friendship and love. I’m dreaming of the boy in the tree and at the exact moment I’m about to hear the answer that I’ve been waiting for, the flashlights yank me out of what could have been one of those perfect moments of clarity people talk about for the rest of their lives. If I were prone to dramatics, I could imagine my sighs would have been heard from the boundaries of the school to the town down below.The question begs to be asked, “Why the flashlights?” Turning on the light next to my bed would have been much less conspicuous and dramatic. But if there is something I have learned in the past five years, it’s that melodrama plays a special part in the lives of those at the Jellicoe School.So, JELLICOE ROAD. This story isn’t quite what I expected. For one thing, there’s a touch of magic in it, though it’s a contemporary YA, not a fantasy novel. For another, it reads very much indeed like a dystopian novel, although it’s not that either. Plus, there’s a definite mystery wrapped around the main story. Here's the back cover copy:Taylor is leader of the boarders at the Jellicoe School. She has to keep the upper hand in the territory wars and deal with Jonah Griggs - the enigmatic leader of the cadets, and someone she thought she would never see again.And now Hannah, the person Taylor had come to rely on, has disappeared. Taylor's only clue is a manuscript about five kids who lived in Jellicoe eighteen years ago. She needs to find out more, but this means confronting her own story, making sense of her strange, recurring dream, and finding her mother - who abandoned her on the Jellicoe Road.The moving, joyous and brilliantly compelling new novel from the best-selling, multi-award-winning author of Looking for Alibrandi and Saving Francesca.Which is all very well, but as you can see from the opening, the protagonist, Taylor, is dreaming about a boy when the story opens. This particular dream, and others, continues to be important through the story and particularly at the end. This is what I mean by a touch of magic.Also, Jellicoe School? The codified warfare between the students of the school, the townies, and the military cadets who spend a few weeks camping nearby in the summer . . . very dystopian feel to this element of the story. The adults don’t know what the heck is going on, even though the war gets pretty violent at times. No actual fatalities, but if the kids hadn’t gotten this all straightened out, I can hardly see how they would have avoided real trouble eventually.The story is not exactly about sorting out this war thing, though. It’s about Taylor getting her own life in order by working out her relationships to her friends at the school, to Chaz Santangelo (one of the Town kids) and most of all Jonah Griggs (leader of the Cadets). It’s also about Taylor sorting out her relationships with her mother, who abandoned her at the school years ago, and Hannah, who has been more or less acting as a mother to her since.So it’s a relationship story. Obviously. Except it’s really two stories braided together, because the story of what happened to Taylor’s mother and Hannah and their friends seventeen years ago is the frame story and also braided through the current-day story. Working out what happened to that earlier group of friends gives JELLICOE ROAD a definite mystery element as well. So it’s complicated.My overall reaction: It’s a pretty dark story. I, unlike whoever wrote the back cover copy, would not have picked the word "joyous" to describe it. What happened seventeen years ago is horrifically grim, and as we find out more about the aftermath, it just gets grimmer. There is a happy ending to that story . . . sort of . . . but the best thing you can say about the contemporary story line is: Taylor and her friends may go through some tough times, but it is *nothing* to what happened to the older generation. And everyone does wind up in a better place at the end than they were in at the beginning, but . . . moving, yes, but joyous?I actually disliked this story at first. I picked it up originally because of Chachic's recommendation, Brandy's comments, and Maureen's review and because the back cover copy sounded interesting. Two of the linked reviews (links now correct; sigh) refer to the confusing beginning. This is true, but it wasn't a problem for me. What was a problem for me is that at the beginning, Taylor is incredibly self-absorbed. I know she was going through a lot, but I really disliked her. Then a friend of hers at the school calls her on that and from that point on, she starts to grow into a much more likeable person. By the end, I liked her a lot. The bit where she tells off Sergeant Santangelo for being angry at his son, Chaz, is one of my favorite scenes. I really enjoyed seeing Taylor grow up and seeing the relationships between her and her friends deepen. Plus, Jonah Griggs! His backstory is *grim*. His background with Taylor is . . . also grim, in unexpected ways. But how he and Taylor figure out what happened in the past and work out their current relationship – all that is pretty much perfect.So, yeah, by the end, I loved this book. Since I was in the mood for emotionally intense contemporaries, I quickly picked up a couple more of Marchetta’s: SAVING FRANCESCA and THE PIPER’S SON.

I'm sitting here with red puffy eyes and a headache, writing this. And it's all Melina Marchetta's fault...Taylor Markham lives at Jellicoe School. She's the head of the school boarders, leading them in a secret military-style battle for territory - in a teen war between the boarders' faction, the Townies and the Cadets that has been going on for generations. Ever since her drug addict mother abandoned her at a 7/11 store a few years back, Taylor has been happy to keep people at arms length. After all, by maintaining a tough exterior, it's easier to hide the hurt. And you can't be abandoned if you don't ever let anyone close enough to abandon you.Yet Taylor feels added responsibility pressing down on her. The disappearance of the closest person to a mother, Hannah, is a betrayal. Before long, however, Taylor moves past her fear of abandonment and worries instead that perhaps Hannah did not disappear of her own accord.Desperate to find her before its too late, Taylor's only clue is a manuscript of Hannah's, holding a story that feels less like fiction and more like a memory. And Taylor starts to wonder...what is it exactly that people are hiding from her? And will she live to find out?***If you can't already guess, this book is ENTIRELY mysterious. I guarantee that unless you have some crystal-ball-prophetic power you will be wondering what the hell is going on with anything for at LEAST the first third (it took me two-thirds, because I'm slower than most).The opening scene in Jellicoe is horribly shocking and angelically beautiful in equal doses. From there the reader is faced with a confusing jumble of people's names and places and actions, with no real way of being able to connect the dots. This is one of the few books where I feel the 100-page rule does not apply, make it 150 pages instead and you'll suddenly understand why I told you to hold on.This book has been called "distinguished" by other book bloggers and I would completely agree with the description. Marchetta has a crafty way of writing that is both mature and accessible.But what I feel this author truly excels at is her ability to create authentic teenage emotion. The relationships between these characters are so real - you feel the thrill of the first hand-touch of two (future) lovers, the fond feelings underlying an insult traded between friends, even the absolute desolation a teen feels when they realise their Innocence is being gobbled up by the Experience monster at an alarming rate. "No one understands us!", they cry.But you're wrong! Melina understands.I had only read Looking for Alibrandi by Marchetta before reading Jellicoe. I thought Alibrandi was a happy, bright little thing, until the book suddenly smacks you in the face with Death. In comparison, though, Jellicoe feels like a school excursion to the local haunted graveyard. Yep, On the Jellicoe Road is all about the ghosts, baby. Ghosts of the past, ghosts of the future, ghosts in dreams and ghosts in trees - pick your favourite flavour of ghost, they're all there. The book's also got this cool military thing going on - the school feels a bit like army barracks and when you pair this with the smalltown, isolated territory, well, you couldn't be blamed for thinking theres a bit of a dystopian thread running through the story.I could go on for a long time about lessons that can be learned here - the book is about journeys rather than destinations, and there are themes of abandonment, and freedom, and the blame game in abundance. Even better for the peeps out there who love a dash of symbolism - there's allusions to such classics as to Kill a Mockingbird and Maurice Sendak's Where the Wild Things Are, and it's totally open for reader's interpretation. I'm sorry I can't really give away more of the actual story, and I may have in fact confused you more, but believe me - it's all part of the master plan. And despite the hugely positive review I'm giving this book I have to come clean - I can't give this book five stars.Marchetta may be a whiz at writing, but she's a terrible surgeon. I feel like I've gone under the knife expecting to be dramatically altered yet healed - after all, my favourite authors have such precision! Instead I wake up to find that my brain thinks only of sad things. I want to curl up into the foetal position and never speak to the world again. This book deals with death, and then some. You can't say you haven't been warned!But hey, all in all, I am happy I read it *stifled sob* and I heartily recommend it *sniffle*. It's a fantastic offering from a fantastic writer and I know now that I'll just have to read Saving Francesca - I've heard brilliant things and it appears to be a lot of people's favourites of all of Marchetta's works... High Expectations, here I come!First though, I need a bit of time to get over this one. I'm exhausted. And I need to go wash my pillowcase.4 stars.A bit o' useless trivia: The original publication title On the Jellicoe Road was changed in the States to the simpler title of Jellicoe Road. Make of that what you will - I don't know what to think!

It breaks my heart (lol not like this book hasn't already broken it), but I cannot give this book five stars.First of all, PUT YOUR TORCHES AND SPEARS DOWN AND LET ME EXPLAIN.I'm going to try and begin justifying my decision by giving you a brief overview of the plot, but this is a hard book to sum up. Basically, there is a girl named Taylor whose prostitute mother abandoned her at a 7-Eleven outlet on Jellicoe Road when she was a child. She goes to Jellicoe School (a boarding school), where the students there are involved in an annual territory war with two other factions of teenagers: the Cadets and the Townies. Once, when she was fourteen, she escaped to try and find her mother, but was found and brought back. In this story, unwanted responsibility is thrust upon her, along with unexpected friendships and a revelation of the past that culminates in a huge storm of a headache and a heartache.Let's begin with the not-so-good so that we can end this on a pleasant note. I felt that the romantic aspects of the book, while portraying a realistic(ish) view of life, served very little purpose. The history that conspires prior to the present setting of this story opens up a world of possibilities that I felt had the capacity to be explored and intertwined with the main story arc, but instead seemed as if it was mostly just there to build sexual tension. Don't get me wrong, it was effective, but didn't contribute much value to the plot. Also, the romance didn't even develop in a very realistic way: in fact, the rate at which it progressed was almost alarming, and I felt that it was just riding on the reader's anticipation to move forward without very much logical flow and sequence (ie. it was pretty obvious from the start who it was always going to be). This, for me, is too great a flaw to ignore in my rating and because of that I've very, very reluctantly knocked it down a star.The good thing is, though, that there is something so magically enticing about this story. A quarter of the way in, I still had no idea what was going on. In the initial pages, the reader is just thrown into a seemingly random segment of Taylor's life with absolutely no introductions to who on earth she is and what kind of system the people there operate on. That's not even counting the bits and pieces of a completely different story chucked in at funny intervals to throw you off. Everything is a blur and it's a chore to piece everything together and get a clearer picture of the whole thing from any bit of contextual knowledge we can get our hands on.But therein lies the magic: the subtlety of the language and the way the plot opens up so gradually is kind of like unfolding a mystery I didn't even know was supposed to exist. It was here that I begun to suspect everything and everyone, and as a result, well... the supposed "plot twists" near the end were not very surprising for me. Rather, I thought it was better as a gradual thing, because while the revealing was taking its time, I was busy shivering with anticipation and oh my goodness is this it is that what you're saying no it can't be no it must be but no oh my goodness you can't do this to me noooo, and by the time everything finally converged, I didn't feel sucker-punched. I felt dead.(sorry, I couldn't resist being a little dramatic)Nah, I don't actually feel dead. It's amazing because there is so much hope in the tragedy that is presented. There are sad moments and parts of what is revealed in the end are undeniably tragic and horrible, but there is so much good that's been done and so many lives changed from all these supposed coincidences. In the end, what you get is the reality of mistakes, but at the same time also, the value of friendship and looking forward.------------------------Edit: Wow after reading so many reviews this sounds so shallow and unbelievably lame. BUT can I just cite this review? Because it is brilliant.

On the Jellicoe Road  is another great book that I could have only found through this site. For some reason, Goodreads-less me was unable to cross paths with it when I was closer in age to the protagonist. I had doubts when I first picked it up. It definitely took me at least six chapters or so to get into and want to know more, I'd read that this was the case for other readers so I just kept going with it. And it was worth it. It takes place mostly in small town present Australia, with briefer jumps back in time in the same location. It's as much about the place as it is the people, and the connections you build with both, especially through tragedy. I don't know why, but for a long time I had a strong opposition to reading YA fiction, even as a young(er) adult! When I was the same age as the protag (17) I tried my hardest to not wander into the teen section at Barnes and Noble because I thought I needed to read more serious works (I don't know where this idea came from...). I'm still fighting this weird book snobbery now but on a more subconscious level because I no longer care what people see me reading. (Well, I guess I have one little clue as to my nervousness. I went through a brief manga phase with my best friend in high school early on, and my Dad gave me the same talk his father had given him when he was still reading comics around that age- which is basically that you just can't anymore. To his credit, at the rate I was reading them and then buying more was probably becoming a little too expensive. But it definitely added to the anxiety of my book choices as it took some pushing on my BF's part to get me into manga in the first place! I've since come to realize that though my Dad is well read in his own exclusive non-fiction way, there are many things he won't experience from reading a little bit of everything. And it's taken me a while to see that not only is that okay, it's really good. Yesh, sorry about that extreme digression!) But because reading was usually a private pleasure for me, no one told me that not all YA is fluff. So, here I sit, once again amazed by another technically YA book, and ready for more. This review was more about me than the book I guess... sometimes that happens.  On the Jellicoe Road  has mystery, action and the perfect amount of romance. It made me laugh and cry (quite literally) and I stayed up until two in the morning to finish it. The reason I give it 4 stars instead of 5 is because I had an unusually hard time visualizing the world, which is critical for me as a reader. There were brief moments when I could see it perfectly, but Marchetta did not put much time into describing the characters beyond vague descriptions and adjectives. While I do sometimes like to alter the appearances of characters I'm reading about (as a kid Hermione had glasses and you couldn't tell me otherwise), I like a foundation to start with. This also applied to the world in general. She really just jumps right into it without much explanation which can be effective in many cases but I think with this story I would have preferred a little more background. All in all, this book opened my eyes a little wider to the power of YA fiction, and I'm ready for more that also set the bar. Teen aisle at Barnes and Noble, I'm ready for you! I can't wait to gift this to my cousins when they're old enough and make sure they never fret over what people see them read (if I can get them off their ipads, yikes). Yes, this review was coffee fueled.

As I rarely read Australian authors, I was expecting somewhat of a departure from the "stock" Young Adult lit books out there. It seems I got, in some ways, what I was expecting, but not in the manner in which I expected it. There were place-names that I didn't recognize (although Sydney was at least familiar-in-name); I had some trouble picturing the landscape not because of the lack of description, but rather because I assume it would be different than the stock landscapes in my head; and I kept wanting the characters to speak in an Australian accent, and I couldn't keep that up for long, as I was too "sucked in" to the characters and story. These things, however, were not the things that kept it from being a typical YA book. "I tell him stories. Lots of stories. About the Jellicoe School students and the Townies and the Cadets from a school in Sydney. I tell him about the war for territory."This book is characterized by two intertwining stories, both of which center on the same geographical location and interrelations among the three "factions" represented in the story (the school, the local "townies," and visiting "cadets"). While I had to go back a few times to re-read the sections of one of the stories as I began to feel my way through the book, some of the connections started to become clear as I continued. This discomfort with the divergent stories ultimately became satisfying, as they unraveled and converged slowly and naturally. Many iterations of YA literature focus on a single "misfit" who ends up saving the world or changing the community. The joy of this story springs from the self-discovery of a number of seemingly normal-and-troubled teenagers, all of whom struggle with reconciling their own identities. Still sounds like a trope, I know... But there's more to it than one might expect from this type of book.The interplay between self-and-origin and self-and-groups leads the main character, along with the people around her, to question where, when, and how identity really develops. Can we be complete if we do not understand where we come from? What are the turning points that make us who we are? Marchetta examines these questions from different viewpoints with a tapestry of answers, highlighting the complexity of being human. With the obvious question of finding out the truth of her parentage and a recently-disappeared parent-figure, the main character finds far more depth of understanding through reading the other story thread, which eventually converges with her own. Through dreams and flashback, this book makes the reader re-examine the glimpses of memory, which are contextualized and reinterpreted through different eyes over time, to seek the truth of SELF. Are we a product of our experiences or the interpretation of those experiences? Can we understand ourselves if we do not understand the motivations of those who have hurt or helped us? Complex but accessible, this book is appropriate for teenagers coming into a realization of identity. It is, however, just as poignant and engaging to a mature reader who may be tired of "typical" YA fiction. The author does not "dumb down" the concepts or complex relationships to cater to an I-want-it-now teenage culture looking forward to the upcoming movie-version. But these action-oriented folks will appreciate the building of suspense, multiple conflicts and layers, and engaging story-line. It's a quick and endearing read that isn't always easy to put down at bed-time.

If there’s a novel that is given more GoodReads love than this one, I have yet to hear of it. Browsing the reviews for Jellicoe Road, I was bombarded with 5-star rating after 5-star rating, glowing review after glowing review. I’ll be honest; after all that, the synopsis could have been about a dancing chicken and I would have rushed over to Amazon to order it. (It’s not, don’t worry.)Taylor Markham is a character taken straight out of a Lifetime movie; she doesn’t know her dad and her rarely-sober mother abandons her at a 7-Eleven, sentencing her to a life at a boarding school and guardianship from the one and only adult in her life to ever truly be there for her, Hannah…until she disappears, too. As if that’s not enough to ratchet the melodrama up to a 10, there’s a tragic story of 5 good friends being told simultaneously, one that happened in the past and slowly answers questions about Taylor’s history.The beginning of Jellicoe Road is very confusing, going back-and-forth between both stories with little to no segue, and no idea of how they match up in any way but location. It took me nearly half the book to really get into the story, and those pages were spent terrified I’d be the odd-man-out yet again, shrugging my shoulders at an enormously loved book and stamping my pessimistic, Debby Downer 2 –or –3-star rating on it. Thankfully, the second half delivered on all the promises the first half laughed at, and I found myself totally immersed in a heart-wrenching story full of lovable characters, many with huge, realistic flaws.What makes Jellicoe Road work is how it deals with the melodrama it contains. With so many tragic events making up the life of one seventeen year old girl, this could have gone terribly wrong in less capable hands. Marchetta manages to make it believable and relatable, never pushing it over-the-top, or cheapening the subject matter. There are no static characters, no Big Bad Guy or flawless hero. Everyone reacts to and is shaped by the events in their lives. This proves to me once again that the most important thing in a story is its characterization, especially in contemporary novels.This is hard for me to rate because of the completely different opinions I had about the first and second half. Ultimately, though you do realize that the beginning needed to be as slow and confusing as it was to make the rest so powerful, I can’t give this the full 5 stars when it took me so long to begin to enjoy it. I do, however, highly recommend it to readers who like a little more substance to their YA, and don’t mind having their emotions put on a rollercoaster of ups and downs.

Taylor is leader of the boarders at the Jellicoe School. She has to keep the upper hand in the territory wars and deal with Jonah Griggs—the enigmatic leader of the cadets, and someone she thought she would never see again.And now Hannah, the person Taylor had come to rely on, has disappeared. Taylor's only clue is a manuscript about five kids who lived in Jellicoe eighteen years ago. She needs to find out more, but this means confronting her own story, making sense of her strange, recurring dream, and finding her mother—who abandoned her on the Jellicoe Road.So many people have been telling me that I have to read this book and now I finally have. I wasn't sure what to expect going in since I've seen such praise for it and I didn't want to be let down. It ended up being an entertaining read and I really liked the characters, but I wasn't as absorbed into the territory wars as I would have liked to have been.Taylor, newly appointed leader of the kids who attend Jellicoe school, was the main character and one that was both intriguing and frustrating. She was going through a lot and trying to deal with it on her own, which led her to passing her responsibilities as leader off on other people. It left a lot of room for growth and she did obviously care about the school and the kids under her care.At first, the plot was a little confusing. It took a few chapters to fully understand who was who and what was going on. Once that was dealt with, it made reading a lot easier. There was a lot of discussion about the territory wars, which was Taylor's boarders vs the townies vs the cadets and each group 'owned' part of the land. There were ways to get more land, to lose land, etc but it never felt like a huge plot detail to me, even though there was a lot about it in the book.What I was more excited about was to find out what had happened to Taylor's guardian, Hannah, who'd disappeared and why the story of five kids from eighteen years old was so important. It did take a few chapters to get used to the switching between the story of those kids and Taylor's group but once I did, it worked really well. The more that was revealed in the story, the more it connected to the present.The writing was absolutely beautiful. There were so many quotable passages. The interactions between characters were all over the place, in a good way. There was fighting and laughter and misery and support and love. It was great and they were my favourite part of the book.

If there's a book in this world that I would have regretted putting down before finishing, it would be this one. Like many other reviewers here, I felt like I was dropped in the middle of a happening and had no choice but to find my own way by rereading some pages to try to figure out what was going on. But when the book finally started taking form, it became well worth the initial confusion. The novel follows two stories of two sets of teens from two different settings, but both are connected by tragedy. One is of the 17-year old heroine, Taylor Markham, who boards the Jellicoe School. Every fall, the “Boarders” fight the “Cadets”, military trainees who camp near the school for a few weeks, and the “Townies”, those who attend the school but live in town, participate in what is called the territory wars where they compete for various trails and buildings in town. In the beginning, she is elected as a leader of the “Borders”. She is highly respected in her faction, but is also known to be stubborn and hard to agree with. It is revealed in the beginning that she was abandoned at a 7-eleven bathroom at the age of 11 by her drug-dependent mother. She is picked up by her guardian, Hannah, who brought her to school on the Jellicoe Road where she works. The only memories she can recollect is sitting on a man’s shoulders, what her mom looked like, and a terrible shooting with the Hermit. The second story follows the tale of five teenagers whose friendship stemmed from a tragic accident. The novel continues as relations with the three factions develop, Taylor learns more about her past, and we out what happened with the five teenagers.The two storylines mixed with everyone seeming to have a “history” with each other was confusing at first, but to those who become stuck on unmotivated- don’t lose heart. Keep reading, because what awaits is nothing short of brilliant. I have to admit, Taylor was not a likeable character at first, but the story gives us insight on her past little by little, and the reader has no choice but to empathize with her. The story comes together in small but dramatic revelations that keep you on your toes. There is a lot about death, despair, anger, hurt, but also love, friendships, hope, and forgiveness. For a book that had so much emotion, Marchetta articulates it in a way that leaves you gutless. Other than the confusing beginning, this was a solid read that has a high recommendation from me.

A stunningly poignant novel. “I remember love. It's what I have to keep on reminding myself. It's funny how you can forget everything except people loving you. Maybe that's why humans find it so hard getting over love affairs. It's not the pain they're getting over, it's the love.”Marchetta weaves two stories decades apart together in such an impressive way! We have the story that Hannah has written about five teenagers who lived on the Jellicoe Road, they were each others family and all that mattered, and how they dreamed of getting out of Jellicoe Road. How fate had other plans. The main story is about Taylor, a seventeen year old who is now the leader of the Jellicoe kids in the territory wars. Taylor is just trying to survive. Abandoned at a 7/11 by her mother when she was 11, she doesn't have many aspirations for herself beyond surviving day to day. She's lost. And this is the complicated and beautifully wonderful story of how she finds herself. “As I walk back to the school on my own, I realise I'm crying. So I go back to the stories I've read about the five and I try to make sense of their lives because in making sense of theirs, I may understand mine.”“Is a person worth more because they have someone to grieve for them?”"Be careful what you wish for," he says with quiet menace, "because I'm about this close to telling you to get the fuck out of my life."I stare at him."What do you want from me?" he asks.What I want from every person in my life, I want to tell him.More.”As always, Marchetta has created an entire cast of characters that you will fall in love with. Her side characters are tenacious and crucial to the story, hardly feeling like side characters at all. And of course, the writing was gorgeous. Over all a really memorable story that I would recommend to anyone!I will definitely be reading it again, I think things will stand out even more then. “And then their voices stopped and their souls stood still and they ceased being who they had been. Because who they were had always been determined by him.”“And suddenly I know I have to go. But this time without being chased by the Brigadier, without experiencing the kindness of a postman from Yass, and without taking along a Cadet who will change the way I breath for the rest of my life.”

this book is pretty much perfect. i'm hesitant to give a 5 star review, but i just might switch it later...at least a 4.5. this is a book with important themes - abandonment, finding one's place in the world, guilt, defining one's self through one's relationships, love (not just romantic love, but love amongst friends). It delves deeply into relationships on all levels, with parental figures, siblings, friends, frenemies, acquaintances, mentors, the whole gamut. and in the end, it is about family, friendship, forgiveness, and the strength of human bonding. it also speaks of the influence that those around us have on the way we live our lives and view the world. in a way, this book gives me hope for humanity; yes, awful things happen, but people are resilient and can find strength in each other.there is so much heart and emotion locked into the pages of this book. (it's been a week or two since i finished reading, yet when i think back on it, all of the emotion comes flooding back). i can't count how many times my heart broke for taylor as she tries to navigate the world that surrounds her, but it's not just taylor for whom my heart breaks, it's narnie and jude, griggs; pretty much everyone has their demons that they carry.as for the plotline, there is slight confusion at the beginning as to what's going on with the different perspectives, but i picked it up rather easily. since the flashbacks/story are told out of sequence, i did end up going back and rereading those portions close to the end just to give myself a proper frame of reference (after everything was revealed of course). i figured out the connection between the stories earlier than i would have liked (and typically this knowledge will ruin a book for me because i prefer to be blind-sided) but found that it didn't bother me in the least. in fact, figuring this out made everything dearer to me, because i knew what some of the outcomes were going to be.characterization was really great. to begin with, there are a lot of characters, but none of them felt superfluous. each has their specific purpose and distinct, realistic personality; all are flawed, as they should be.really, really impressed with this book and hope to read more like it.

Ya'll, I wanted to love this one but I just couldn't. It's gotten amazing reviews, and it was certainly okay, but it just didn't do it for me.I thought the beginning was convoluted. We start with a story, it's going great, then bam! New story with new people and new places and no word on what happened to the old story. It takes a bit of reading to catch on, and you do, but I thought it was jarring to jump back and forth with no context.We immediately jump into the Townies/Cadets/House wars but we're not told why. Maybe I'm unusual here, but I wanted to know why these 3 groups were fighting over land and taking hostages and literally beating each other up. I may have been able to get into the story more if I had this background information.The plot in itself was quite good, unusual. It set up a lot of questions that I wanted to keep reading to find out the answers to. Like, where is Taylor's mom? Is she dead? If not, why hasn't she come for Taylor? What about her dad? Why are the land wars going on? What happened with Griggs years ago?There were a lot of characters and Marchetta did a decent job of giving them their own personalities. Some of them could have used a little more rounding out, but nothing was a deal breaker.The dialogue was good, quite realistic. There were a few terms or expressions that I had never heard of. I assume they are common in Australia. They were not bothersome and added to the feel of the story.There was no sexy hotness at all, which kind of surprised me, as there were a ton of teenagers living in a boarding school with little adult supervision. But maybe I have a skewed idea of what boarding school is like... There were a few nice kissing scenes, and 1 sex scene that was tentative and sincere.The Sum Up: It took a long time for me to finish reading this one. Whether that was because of the length of the story, or because it just couldn't keep me interested, I had a hard time deciding. I was ready to give this 3 stars until the last 4th of the book when it became more interesting. I especially enjoyed the ending, which avoided being too sappy or clichéd.

Re-read: December 19, 2017 This is one of those books that demand to be read over and over again. It’s a touching story that follows Taylor Markham, whose trying to find the mystery of her mother. Honestly, this book is so darn good that it hurts to read sometimes because it’s so full of wisdom. I love Taylor and being in her head. Although, I wish there was a little more to her grief, I absolutely recommend this book. With the second time reading, everything makes so much more sense. I absolutely loved reading this time around. And will definitely be re-reading this again in 2018.* * * * *Original ReviewOfficially found the love of my life: Jonah Griggs. I can't believe that I've owned this book for four years and haven't picked it up until now. This book was outstanding and the writing (oh my!!) was gorgeous. I will definitely re-read Jellicoe Road before the year ends.

Synopsis: At age eleven, Taylor Markham was abandoned by her mother at the 7-11. At fourteen, she ran away from boarding school, only to be tracked down and brought back by a mysterious stranger. Now seventeen, Taylor's the reluctant leader of her school's underground community, whose annual territory war with the Townies and visiting Cadets has just begun.This year, the Cadets are led by Jonah Griggs, and Taylor can't avoid his intense gaze for long. This is the same Jonah that Taylor spent 3 days with while she was running away trying to find her mother, and before the Brigadier finds her, and brings her back to her boarding school.To make matters worse, Hannah, the one adult Taylor trusts, has disappeared, and nobody will tell her where Hannah went. This is an amazing story that tracks not only Taylor, but also the past story of her mother Tate, and a group of 4 kids that were brought together by tragic circumstances. It interweaves both stories, and they finally come together for a nice ending.Taylor's character has alot of anger issues to deal with, but in reality, she's entitled to them. Her mother, Tate, moved her around so many times as a child, and told her she had different names each place they landed, that when she is finally abandoned at a 7-11, she realizes that she is alone. She can't remember her father, Webb, who died years ago, and who along with Tate, Narnie, Fitz, and Jude (the Brigadier). where the original pransters on campus.Marchetta has interweaven the stories between the two groups; the past, and the present, very well. You get a feeling as you are reading that the two will somehow piecing themselves together, and they do. The only negative was the mini sex scene between Taylor and Jonah. I didn't think it needed to be there. It just seemed a little bit immature and hurried. I still rate this book excellent and a must read.

The first third of the book was fairly confusing for me and it took me a bit to get the gist of both what was being written and what was going on. But...it was good enough to keep me going and it was worth it. A good, though not overly complicated story. It was very different from anything I've ever read and I enjoyed it quite a bit. I will definitely be reading more by Melina Marchetta.

Taylor was abandoned on Jellicoe Road by her mother. All she has in Hannah, a woman who has been taking care of her while she stays at a school there. If you are one of those people who have been meaning to read this but haven't yet, set some time aside and devour this one. You may want to read it again right after you finish so you can see things again with all your new information. This is 100% worth the read.First Lines:"My father took one hundred and thirty-two minutes to die. I counted."Favorite Lines:"And then he told me to close my eyes. I reviewed this late in 2008 for School Library Journal and found it complex, rich, and ultimately rewarding, but I am still surprised that it won the Printz Award. I would love some good reads types to read it and let me know what they think."School Library Journal (December 1, 2008)Gr 8 Up-For years, three factions-Townies, Cadets (city kids doing a six-week outdoor education program), and Jellicoe School students-have engaged in teen war games in the Australian countryside, defending territorial borders, negotiating for assets, and even taking hostages. Taylor Markham, a 17-year-old who was abandoned years ago by her mother, takes on leadership of the boarding school's six Houses. Plagued with doubts about being boss, she's not sure she can handle her Cadet counterpart, Jonah Griggs, whom she met several years before while running away to find her mother. When Hannah, a sort of house mother who has taken Taylor under her wing, disappears, Taylor puzzles over the book manuscript the woman left behind. Hannah's tale involves a tragic car accident on the Jellicoe Road more than 20 years earlier. Only three children survived, and Taylor discovers that this trio, plus a Cadet and a Townie, developed an epic friendship that was the foundation of the many mysteries in her life and identity, as well as of the war games. While the novel might put off casual readers, patient, thoughtful teens will remain to extract clues from the interwoven scraps of Hannah's narrative, just as Taylor does, all the while seeing the collapse of the barriers erected among the three groups over the years. Elegiac passages and a complex structure create a somewhat dense, melancholic narrative with elements of romance, mystery, and realistic fiction.-Suzanne Gordon, Peachtree Ridge High School, Suwanee, GA Copyright 2008 Reed Business Information."

I wanted to ponder my review of Jellicoe Road after finishing it. The beginning was chaotic and confusing - so many characters to learn and two major story lines being told simultaneously. I had read reviews about this and knew going into it that I would need to try to learn each of the characters for who they were, and to not try immediately to figure out how (or even IF) the stories converged. I think this approach worked out well, though I did find it difficult to keep up with who was who and the little sub-stories that were told within these two main stories. (See, a bit confusing)!However, once I got past the initial 'who's who' feeling, I began to feel deeply connected to this book. I wanted to know how things would unravel. I could see the pieces coming together. I began to see the BRILLIANCE behind Melina Marchetta's writing. Her story-telling technique was spot on. Sure it was slow-going and a little difficult at first, but there's no question why this book won such a prestigious award. Overall, my favorite aspect of the story was how all these random teenagers came together. In each of the story lines there were 5 random kids who really didn't 'belong' together as a group of friends, but against all odds, they became the best of friends. Jonah was probably my favorite character. There was so, so much I wanted to understand about him. I had so many questions and I wanted to know WHY and HOW he would become a main part of the story. This book made me think about the characters when I wasn't reading. It made me try to figure out the plot line. I tried to weave it all together. Read. This. Book. (and then pick up something else by Marchetta)!

A gorgeous, poignant story with a writing style that awed me; not because it was particularly lyrical or unusual, but because it was so real and emotional.Taylor Markham lives at Jellicoe School on Jellicoe Road, a beautiful place in the Australian bush. But Jellicoe Road is also a place of memories, and those memories are tragic, stunning, binding things that form the incredible roots of this novel. Everywhere on Jellicoe Road, memories tangle with the present, until you realize that the author has woven a stunning tapestry of generations, families, loves, and friendships that spans years. The connections are amazingly intricate and yet don't stretch belief in the slightest. The emotions felt are raw and real and beautifully human. The identities that are steadily revealed with keep you guessing and gasping with every page.There's the present-day rivalries between the Jellicoe School kids, the Townies, and the visiting army Cadets. There's Taylor's struggles to understand her parents' abandonment, her loving but distant caretaker Hannah, the school kids under her care, and the sharp-edged Cadet named Jonah with whom she shares a history. And there's the story of the five kids who used to live on Jellicoe Road, five kids brought together by a single horrific accident, who loved each other and Jellicoe Road with all their hearts and continue to affect the present in more ways than can be imagined.With so many facets, you'd think there would be things rushed or left unsaid by the end, but the author guides every bit of the story to a pitch-perfect conclusion; not sappy, but so pure and wonderful. Each character is so well-written, even the side characters. Completely and totally recommended.

Taken from my full review here:Book Title: Jellicoe RoadAuthor: Melina MarchettaPublication Date: 2007Genres: YA Fiction, Realistic FictionGoodreads Rating: 4.18 Stars My Rating: 4.5 StarsRecommended To: Anyone who is feeling lost; Anyone who wants to read about finding family1.
