55/52On the Jellicoe Road is about Taylor, the product of a series of unfortunate events, starting with a deadly car crash and ending with her being dumped at 7/11 by her mom. On paper, things started looking up from there. But when you get a shitty start in life, it isn't that easy to trust people, open up to new friendships or allow yourself to fall in love. In  On the Jellicoe Road, Taylor learns how to do all of those things, while fighting a war that isn't a war, and while figuring out how her life is interwoven with that of The Five, a group of friends formed by the worst of circumstances, and torn apart by even shittier ones.On the Jellicoe Road is also a book that had me really confused for the first few chapters. I didn't understand what the whole war was all about. I couldn't discover the purpose of the unchronological flashbacks, and I kept feeling like I was missing something. But about one-third in, things started to make sense and I got caught up in Taylors quest to discover what she is all about. It's one of those books where you'll appreciate the first few messy chapters later on, because everything starts to make sense eventually, and you can feel really smart for figuring it all out. What I loved most about this book is how genuine everything feels. Before On the Jellicoe Road, I only read Marchetta's fantasy novels, so I didn't really know what to expect in this genre. But she definitely owns it. Rich, delightfully flawed characters that you can relate to, even if you're nothing like them, and a setting that makes you feel nostalgic for a place you've never been and will never visit. Highly recommend this one!

An amazing read, especially when you get about halfway through. I generally try not to give away spoilers, but I'm going to clue you in on part of a spoiler here, because otherwise the first part of the book would be nearly impossible to follow. There are large sections of italics in the first half of the book. This is another story, written by another character in the book (not saying who, although the reader will figure it out quickly). The first half is a bit disjointed at times, which makes sense because the main character, Taylor Markham, isn't sure where she fits in. She finds herself the reluctant leader of a private school dorm, thrust into planning the annual schemes the school puts up against the Cadets and Townies. Taylor's life is shaken further when Hannah, an adult counselor of sorts who lives on the school grounds, vanishes overnight. Taylor's mother abandoned her near the school when she was 11, and the teen always saw Hannah as a mother figure. She is especially worried because of additional reports of young girls going missing. In addition, it seems like Taylor's closest peers and adults know more about her past than she does -- are are reluctant to give her any details. As I said -- the first half of the book is a bit disjointed, but it's not too bad. Things finally get rolling with the confrontations between the teens at the school, the Townies and the Cadets, and the story finds its stride when the students go on vacation. At that point is when the book becomes purely exhilerating, and the wrap-ups end on many unexpected twists. Some language, but fairly clean overall; good for 8th/9th grade and up.

4 Stars There are books which you like. A lot. But they don't have the same effect on you that it did on everyone. They didn't make you cry. Nor did they make you feel anything too deep. This is one of those books that you'll always remember fondly. That you'll think of as one of those books which gave you new perspective while you read it. Captivated you and gave you this sense of peace at the same time. Made you think that even though so many bad things happened there is after all some good too. And when you finish it, you get this strong sense of satisfaction even though the ending may not be your happily ever after type. In my eyes that is one of the greatest accomplishment an author can make. Ok so critically speaking, for the first approximately 25% of the book, you'll be wondering WHY IS THIS EVEN THERE ?? And feel a sense of mystery at the same time. Trust me, I about made a thousand guesses about what the actual plot is while reading the first 25% and my guesses ranged from the lead being in coma and imagining things in her comatose state of mind to her living in an alternate world where all the people she's seeing around actually being hidden aliens. ( Hey don't laugh !!! ) But all I'll tell you is. Just enjoy the book and let the story unravel.

I give this book 5 stars after page 130. The beginning was not particularly enthralling, but the story definitely evolved towards the end. I can see why some people may not enjoy this book- usually my favourites capture my attention in the first few pages. On The Jellicoe Road was definitely an exception to my rule. The second half of the book excused the slow beginning.The emotion in the book was so raw and touching. Once you understood the relationships and how everyone was linked, you could not help but be affected by the characters' stories. The story went in an opposite direction to what I was expecting by reading the first 100 or so pages. The plot seemed a bit silly and unemotional at the beginning, but it takes a quick change. I don't really want to go into the storyline, because it takes an unpredictable course. When I read this book I had no idea what to expect, and my confusion wasn't really resolved until I was half way into the story. I had many theories as to where the story would go, and most of them were way off. I advise reading this book with no previous knowledge of the plot. If a friend has spilled it to you, well what a shame. Although it was frustrating at the time, I'm glad I was left in the dark. This is by far Melina Marchatta's best work.

I will freely admit that I didn’t really get hooked on this book until I was over a hundred pages in. In fact, this is a book I have picked up and started several times before and ended up putting it down. I think the only way I got through it this time is because I made a commitment to read it, and I am so glad I did. Jellicoe Road is a story about tragedy and triumph, family and friends, hope and loss. It tells the story of two families, the Markham’s and the Schroeder’s, and their lives on the Jellicoe Road. Our primary narrator for the novel is Taylor Markham, who was abandoned by her mother at a 7-eleven on Jellicoe Road when she was 11 years old. As Taylor reluctantly accepts a leadership role at her school and leads the war against the townies and cadets, she also starts down a path of self discovery, where she discovers her own history and who she really is.Nothing in this novel is as it seems and it takes quite a while for the pieces of the puzzle to begin to fall into place. Once you get to that part, though, it becomes nearly impossible to put the book down. Highly recommended.Cautions for sensitive readers: There is some profanity in the book and some sexual situations. There is also a violent car accident that is referred to with some graphic depictions.

My first go at reading Jellicoe Road was slow and wrought with confusion. I really wanted to get absorbed by the story because so many of my YA librarian colleagues were in love with the book, but I only made it through about 100 pages before it was due back to the library. A few months later, I decided to give it another chance and I’m glad I did. This time I was enchanted by Taylor Markham and the almost magical outback world she inhabits. Marchetta has beautifully interwoven the scattered stories of Narnie, et al. with Taylor’s present, creating a subtle, but increasingly urgent, mystery for both Taylor and the reader. Clues dropped earlier in the novel don’t become apparent until the end when all the dialogue, memories, and interactions of the characters come together. In Jellicoe and its environs, she has created a tremendous sense of place that grounds the story and becomes its own character of sorts. The territory wars between the students, the townies, and the cadets reinforce the importance of place in the book. I did find it cumbersome at first to keep track of all the characters and their relationships, especially the kids in Hannah’s story, but it all becomes clear in the end. Overall, Marchetta crafted a timeless, enjoyable, and extremely captivating novel.

4.5 stars. I've docked a half star for some of the dialogue. It was hard to believe that people would talk to one another that way. The story itself is unique and wonderful. So many rich, deep, fully fleshed out characters and I really enjoyed that she didn't lay out the story matter of fact but kind of let you guess at it some. I really liked the two story lines going on at the same time, the one with the original five and then the present day stories had enough similarities to make it interesting but enough differences to keep it from being boring or feeling like I was reading it twice. I felt like the ending was a tinnnny bit rushed, from the part where the fire occurs. I was really appreciate of the twists in this story and how neatly they tied everything up, even questions like "what was Webb thinking when he died", and "why do they keep mentioning that damn serial killer?" were answered. While I did guess the majority of how this book would pan out (who was whose parents and that the brigadier was not who he seemed to be) I still thoroughly enjoyed the ride. The idea of Jellicoe is just really beautiful. I imagine the original fives summer days being full of heat and sweating soda bottles and gauzy edges. It was really just beautifully written.

Taylor was abandoned on the Jellico Road when she was 11 years old. She was taken in my Hannah, a caretaker at the Jellico School, a place for wards of the state to go to school until they are 18. Behind the seeming quiet of Jellico School is a feud that goes back before Taylors time there, a secret war going on between the students of Jellico School, the townies and the cadets. Taylor has just been named the leader of the students and it is hear job to regain precious territory from the cadets and townies. Taylor is surprised to find out that her enemy, the leader of the cadets, is the same boy she ran away with when she was 14. When Hannah disappears, Taylor decides to try to unravel the mystery around Hannah, her mother and the hermit. Enemies become unexpected friends when the leaders of the townies and cadets help Taylor in her search.I was super confused when I started reading this book, it really needs a map and a character guide. Because they refer to several people by their last names, I couldn't even keep track of who was a guy and who was a girl. But after about 200 pages I really got into it. I can see why it won the award. It was a beautiful book with some unexpected twists.

After giving it some thought, I definitely preferred this book over Finnikin of the Rock. Which is odd for me, since my tastes usually run to fantasy instead of contemporary works.I thought the characters arced brilliantly in both mysteries that were unfolding. The movement in time between the two stories was perfectly timed and switching between them didn't feel cheap or contrived at all. They were both genuinely compelling stories that had satisfying conclusions.The only thing that I thought it loses points for was the fact that you aren't clear at first that the main character doesn't exist in both stories. So I kept trying to figure out the math of how the two could fit together, which took me out of the moment for a while at the beginning. But I carried on and once I figured it out found it utterly compelling.For some reason it reminds me of Kit Pearson's A Handful of Time, which is one of my all-time favourite classics. This is just a teenage, sexier, Australian story that is every bit as compelling and satisfying to read. Also, just as a side note, I do believe that this is the first book I've ever read that was set in Australia, which is kind of cool, in and of itself.

I haven't read too many YA novels, and this one has just set the bar REALLY high for all future ones I'll read. What a great coming-of-age story. I finished this at around 3 am this morning, so any immediate reactions I felt were quickly replaced by sleep. So instead I'm gonna make another list now :)Things I liked:-the puzzle slowly unravelling-the progression and believability of the romances-the five kids from the 1980s-how Marchetta excelled at writing the thoughts and speech of a teenager - all the insecurities, depression, anxieties, etc. -the setting of Jellicoe-THE MESSAGES ABOUT FRIENDSHIPThings I didn't like:-narrator sometimes getting way too emo and bitchy to those who care about her (sure she SOMETIMES had reason to, but I felt like slapping her and telling her to snap out of it)-all the boundary and hostage negotiations in the territory war-in fact, the territory war itself - I just didn't care for it at all and still not even sure I got the point of it-too many uses of the phrase "just say"...is it an Australian thing? Personally, I'm more used to "what if"I think this book has high re-read value; the second time around will provide such a different experience now that the full story is known.

First of all I look back and I can't believe it took me over a month to finish this book. In all honesty the first half of the book was just at such a slow pace, I had moments where I wanted to put it down. But I'm so glad that I stuck it through! The last half of the book was amazing! All the pieces of the puzzle fit together and all the unanswered questions were finally answered. What made me love this book aside from the slow pacing is that once you finish the book the story itself is so heartwarming and it's just something I have never read of before. I find the story unique and exquisite. If you've ever watched the movie Stand by Me (involves a group of close friends) I'm sure you'll throughly enjoy this novel! This book covers romance, death, family, and most importantly friendship. The strong bond between the faces in the photograph is out of this world, it's hard to find friendship like that these days and their simplicity on the values of life just made me mire drawn to them. Already mentioned above are some of the characters; all of the characters had a realistic touch to them. Every single character is outstandingly lovable. And lastly what made this novel impeccably remarkable was that each character had a story when they were all in a story themselves.

I had such a disconnect with the first half of this book. I'd pick it up, I'd put it down. Weeks would pass. I'd pick it up, I'd put it down. A month or two would go by, and the same thing. By the time I was vested, I frequently had to go back in the book to reacquaint myself with some of the characters, especially the flash back group: Narnie, Tate, Fitz, etc. (See I still can't recall all of their names. But "etc" married/Hooked up with Tate..that much I remember). Someone killed someone? Did the friend kill the other friend or was it the serial killer? No wait, I think I have it. So what we have is...My bad memory vs a somewhat confusing book...at least at first. But the book won me over, and by the last third I really couldn't put it down anymore. It all finally came together, and the initially confusing disjointed stories and characters wove together seamlessly into a rather beautiful story of yearning, redemption, forgiveness, love, and all that important stuff. I would read it again. I think I NEED to read it again to catch it all, but next time I doubt that I will put it down.

This was a perfect summer read. The story is beautifully crafted, as well as the characters, their interactions, their banter, and their struggles. This book makes your heart feel all fuzzy and warm at times, and it squeezes it at others. The sweetness and sadness of two stories are beautifully intertwined and the way both are slowly revealed keeps you glued to the pages. Before you notice, the ride is over and you want to give it another go to savour it once again.Most of the reveals were foreseeable, although some still had an impact once they were officially out there. Still, knowing beforehand who did what or who was who didn't diminish my enjoyment. While those reveals are crucial to the development of the story, they don't define the story alone. This is as much about what brings both stories together, as it is about how the people in these stories are shaped by what happened, even if they don't know it themselves.If you haven't read this yet, please do not go looking for more reviews. The least you know, the better. Let the story swallow you up little by little, and you won't be disappointed.

It has taken me some time to get around to this, but I had to ramp up the YA reading in advance of the new cohort of students starting our program soon, so I basically sat down and read 300 pages of this book on a Thursday night. The beginning of the book was really hard to follow because there were two stories going on and lots of characters that weren't really described much - just named. And you have to read 50 pages until you get to the second principal character. But getting there does help sort the narrative out a bit, and it starts getting clearer from there. The plot of the book turns out to be much richer than I'd originally thought it would be based on my reading of the back cover (which I should have known, since the book won a Printz Award), and I was pleased and moved. There's also a strong female protagonist - but that's not very unusual in YA these days, is it? (Yay!) It's also nice that it is set in Australia, because so much of the YA genre comes out of the US. It's definitely not my favorite YA book of all time (those honors go to Rainbow Rowell, John Green, and Jay Asher), but it's a solid, worthwhile read.

(I will probably say all this again at book club :)) First the good: I loved the characters and found that I cared what happened to them. I thought the writing was amazing because the author is unfolding a mystery throughout the book and she doesn't spell it out for the reader, but you feel like you are connecting the dots on your own. She has different ways of telling the story and it keeps you reading. It wasn't paranormal, which is a nice break from what I've been reading. The characters felt real and I was sad to end the book because I wanted to know what happens to them throughout life.The bad: There is no setting at the beginning of the book which makes the first 60 pages really confusing. There are A LOT of characters to keep track of and how they are connected to other characters and other time periods. There is a bit too much tragedy (with that said, there is still a feeling of hope throughout the book).I liked it, but would be hesitant to recommend it to just anyone-a book lover would enjoy it (Jami), but the average reader might get frustrated and quit before the good parts.

Jellicoe Road took me a while to get into. The first chapter was intriguing enough, but the other first 1/4 of the book took a bit to get back to that initial grabbing of my attention.The story is really about two separate groups of people, one the current teenagers that the main character is writing about. The second group is told about in a story that the guardian of the main character has left behind that the MC reads throughout the story.There are no big surprises in Jellicoe Road, but Melina Marchetta's writing is strong enough that the element of surprise is unnecessary. The story exposes both the past and present for both groups of characters, with their stories being nicely interwoven, each dependent upon the other for the final resolution to come about.As someone older than the older group of characters being written about, I appreciated the way Marchetta handled the older characters, making them believable and sympathetic. They had their own problems and some of those problems required the pushing of the younger group to work through. Well worth the read.

People hear me out. I've had this book for god knows how long. I bought this because the reviews were mostly excellent and this book has a medal printed award on it and I assume it was very very amazingly written. Without a moment's hesitation I 'added it into cart'. I tried reading it years ago but godddddd, it was utterly confusing and so slowwwwww I just had to put it down. After that I tried again but I just couldn't get past the 3rd chapter. Fortunately this year, I read the reviews again on GR and they kept saying how good and amazing it is (( but I still couldn't understand which part was amazing until now)) but I went with my heart and to keep ploughing through even though I was seconds away from giving up. THIS BOOK REQUIRES WILL POWER AND STRENGTH TO MAKE YOU STAY so I forced myself.I FINISHED IT FUHH *wipes eyebrow* finally and I got to say, it was amazing indeed. Just stay with the book till the end. Trust me. Everything will reveal itself after all the bewilderment you went through.[In the end I did not need myself some kleenex]

One brief comment: audiobook is not the way to go with this one, if you're listening on your iPod and keep making stupid mistakes when trying to go back a sentence or two which result in your losing your place altogether. TOO MANY chapters begin essentially the same way!That said, I liked the narrator. Not sure exactly why I liked this one so much, as there were a lot of things I thought inadequately reasoned (like why Hannah didn't just tell Taylor what was going on, or why Taylor didn't recognise a character she'd no reason to forget) and I slightly resented coming to love a character who had deliberately stomped on another character's fingers (with all his considerable body weight *and* heavy boots). Things like that. And the seeming lack of necessity for there to have been QUITE so much tragedy and misfortune in everyone's lives, except to leave things where they needed to be. But then sometimes that's the way it goes with a book and reading pleasure is reading pleasure, even if you do have more doubts about the book than you might.

I was so close to close this novel, create a new list, name it as "dropped", put this novel under the new created dropped list, and never in my lifetime I'll continue reading this ever, but I didn't do this and I'm glad that I didn't. At first I didn't understand anything till page 50 or something, I thought that may be I should have read something related first, or maybe I missed something :D, because I had no idea of what was going on. What are the "Cadets", "Townies" or "us" that taylor kept referring to. WHO ARE THESE PEOPLE and WHY THERE'S A WAR and WHAT'S THIS ALL ABOUT :D, oh and the story of the "five", I swear I didn't know a thing of what was going on :D. I wasn't going to continue it at all, and I kept asking myself how come someone could rate this with 5 stars, until everything made sense to me, and I gathered all of what I've read and I began to understand and finally to like it. So, my sincere apology It's a very good novel. It was so emotional and heart-breaking, and I'm sure I'll be thinking about it for a while.

Frustratingly emotional and addictive..that would be my two words in describing this book..At first this book was so confusing, it was bit hard for me to grab on "what is actually going on", I was even annoyed with the female main character at first (but sometimes she still keeps being annoying), and everything was big scramble pieces of puzzle!But please keep on reading, coz everything starts becoming clearer and you can see the whole picture of what is truly happening..This book is sooooooooooooooooo freakin' emotional, I even took a day off after two days reading this book and then off watching bunch of episodes from Arrow, Under the Dome, to Supernatural.. Then afterwards I finished this book for good..This book is fast-paced, intriguing, confusing at first, frustrating and heart-wrenching.. There's something about YA contemporary real-life-issues, it's just so real and it can happen to anyone, that makes it more emotional than it already is..Okay than.. I need to breathe now..

4/4.5 You have to give this book a chance, even if in the beginning you aren't sure. It's not uninteresting at the start. It's complicated and mysterious and you're convinced it's going to be feckless but it's not. It's so not! I recently read a book (The Scorpio Races) where it took 200 pages before I finally cared, even a little, about what was happening. It was a good book but a bit agonizing in the beginning. Jellicoe is similar only in that it might require 200 pages for you to realize you care but I promise you that you cared way before, and you didn't even know. I also promise that the final 200+ pages are distinguished. This, like every Melina Marchetta book I've read is well worth the effort required. I don't use the word effort in a negative way. Reading generally is effortless. Marchetta's books though are a cooperative experience and truly require your attention and commitment. They demand loyalty and in return you become a beloved member of the family, as beautifully dysfunctional as they are, and your heart is exceedingly rewarded.

I read this because it happened to be available on Overdrive (ebooks available through the public library). I really didn't know what to expect -- I read the excerpt here on Goodreads and thought it would be another novel about teen angst and death. Which it is, but...it was a really odd read! At first I was confused -- who are these voices speaking, and what do they have to do with anything? The main narrator isn't the girl from the excerpt on Goodreads? Why do these kids have a war going on? What year is it? Where are they? It took a while (probably half the book) for me to figure out a lot of this. It was kind of like reading a sequel without having read the first book -- they kept referring to past events as if one ought to know what they were talking about.And all of this annoyed me at first, but about half way through things really took off, more was revealed, and ROMANCE came into the equation. I ended up staying awake until nearly 2 a.m. to finish the book.

This book was beautiful, as many people on here said it would be. I usually fall in love with the language of a book, the lyrical way that words are put together. That has nothing to do with why I enjoyed this book. The story was innocent and honest. It reached me on a level different than most books. I am no stranger to the void that death can leave inside a person, but the emotions that Marchetta writes about are foreign to me. The characters are pretty complex, the emotions are intense and gripping. I actually felt for the characters, but they aren't characters who would need people to feel sympathy for them. It is kind of wild and disorienting.My favorite part though, and hopefully you won't think this is stupid, the fact that Marchetta does not make having sex for the first time this glamorous and amazing act. I am sure for some people it is, but reality is not often what books and movies make it out to be. I was pleased to read something believable.

The first 15% or so of this book I had no idea what was happening, and if my friends' reviews hadn't all been so positive and said "at first I was super confused but then it got really good", I'd have abandoned it. But I'm so glad I didn't! I still am a little confused by the "war" between the townies and the students and the cadets, and every time the book mentioned something like Google or Dancing With The Stars I found it jarring because in my head this book took place in a dystopian sort of world where things like that don't exist, and I'm not sure why. But I'm so glad I picked this book up and that I kept reading past the confusing beginning. It's not at all the type of book I would normally pick up, but Jennie @shelikespurple listed it as one of her top 11 books she read in 2014 and all the others she listed that I read were really good so I decided to trust her, and man was that a smart choice.

This is a hard book for me to review because while I think, ultimately, that this was brilliant and beautiful, I have to ask:did there HAVE to be so much flippin' capture the flag!??! I'm all for compelling and creative narrative techniques, but the fact that it took 200 pages for the main character to cotton onto something I'd kind of assumed right off the bat was frustrating. I appreciate the attempt at being non-linear, but I wish everyone had had fewer nicknames and titles to help clear things up. Like...A chart of cadets, townies, and Jellicoe kids would have been INVALUABLE. The prose was gorgeous, but so wrought at times, it distracted from what the heck was going on. So yes, I loved a lot about this book and Jonah Griggs can call me, like, ANY TIME HE WANTS, but still. But still. The confusion: I'm holding it against you, Marchetta.That being said, this book will need a reread & will probably be a lot more satisfying on a second go.

2015 Reading Challenge - A book that made you cryActual rating: 3,5 starsOkay, whoa, I didn't expect I'd cry with this book. But I did. I cried like a baby at 2am and I regret nothing.So, the first part of this book is quite confusing. I didn't know what I was getting myself into, and the storylines were mixed altogether so it was a bit hard to follow. But it was a fast read, to be honest, and once you start to get to know all the characters, it's even faster.Fact is some things regarding Taylor's story are really predictable, yet so I was with my heart on my sleeve and heavily breathing each time a new revelation came. Sincerely, I don't know if I'd recommend this book or not. I'm almost sure it's the time I read this one what made me feel as many feelings as I felt, with my heart wrenching. Go, give it a try and find out by yourselves if it's worth it or not. For me, it was.

I only got to truly appreciate the plot halfway through reading the book, since I initially found the story too fragmented. But when the plot began to pick up the pace, it was a really enjoyable read. With the book classified as teen fiction, one would think that it would be about a confused protagonist that would eventually become whole once she found romance. Thankfully, "On the Jellicoe Road" does not follow that path, giving us a strong-willed yet believably flawed character like Taylor and focusing on her main struggle of discovering her past instead of merely becoming another "star-crossed lovers" plot with the territory wars and all. The ending was happy yet quite sad at the same time, for it was there that the reader can piece together the sequence of events and the miserable future that befell on the five kids on the Jellicoe road.

I suppose the beginning is as good a place to start as any. Except that the beginning of this book left me confused and disoriented. It was disjointed and choppy, and I found myself slogging through the first few chapters. I had a hard time keeping the characters straight, and too many details were being thrown at me from all directions. But boy! Am I ever glad that I kept going! It opened up into a story I could relate with, even though I have never had anything even remotely similar happen to me! Our protagonist, Taylor Markham, is so absolutely messed up, and her flaws are what make her so incredible. So complete in her self-destructiveness, you can't help but feel drawn into her pain. As a side note, I really enjoy reading books from the southern hemisphere. I find the language differences so endearing. kerb = curb, pashing = kissing

It's a very good thing that I'd heard so much about this book before I started. Otherwise, I wouldn't have finished it. The first 150 pages were slow, confusing and frustrating for me. Then, the book blossomed and became beautiful, compelling, heart-breaking, life-affirming, and just about every other superlative I could come up with. When I finished reading, I held the book to my chest and just stared into space for a while. That's when I know I've read something wonderful.I just wish I could have gotten to that point sooner.In the end, it was so good, I'm tempted to read it again with the ending already known to me so I can understand all the confusing parts that are going on in the first 150. That. Good.But I still have to hold back from the 5th star because of the first part. I seriously wanted to quit reading.Talk about a roller coaster ride.

Wow, what an emotional ride. This book follows a girl named Taylor and her journey as well as the journey of a group of five friends which runs parallel to Taylor's story. Due to the fact that I listened to this story as an audiobook, I found it extremely difficult and confusing differentiating between the two stories and it took me an embarrassingly long time to figure out that there actually were two stories running simultaneously. The two stories as individuals were amazing and the way that they entwined together was so heartbreaking and heartwarming at the same time and when combined with the character development? Amazing. Melina Marchetta is a genius :)(view spoiler)[Side note: I seriously loved the concept of the territory wars. So cool. Also, all the Aussie references, loved it :D (hide spoiler)]

Read this in about a day and a half. It's been a while since I've let myself get that immersed in one book. Marchetta's writing kept me involved, leaving me a bit breathless when I had to put it down. Though it wasn't entirely unpredictable to me, the unfolding happened rather masterfully: suspense between clue and reveal was timed palpably. I hate when the only thing pulling me through a book is the author's refusal to disclose information. Marchetta kept the clues and the reveals coming...so I pushed through the book intrigued instead of being dragged along disgruntled.It also kinda made me wish I'd had some great love as a teenager, instead of the smattering of one-way crushes. But then I'm also glad I didn't. Not sure I could have handle the breakup of a great love at that age.

Oh Melina Marchetta! I can't stand how much I love your books! Jellicoe Road is another story of flawed, cracked, injured characters who somehow manage to love each other so deeply (and yet still imperfectly) that they fill each other's flawed souls and make the dark, frustrating world a beautiful place. One moment I loathe these characters and the next I'm crying for their joy or sorrow. There are very gritty, painful parts of this book that would prevent me from recommending it to a teen. Normally I despise the sort of books that glamorize bad behavior, but Marchetta always makes me love each and every one of her characters--- no matter how desperately I despise the choices they make. This is my favorite of her books. Gripping story, fantastic characters, beautiful writing.

I do not give out 5 stars easily, which is why this book only has 4 stars for me. It came really close to the 5 stars, though.I will not tell you anything about this story, because I feel it is best to go into a book not knowing anything other than the blurb on the back.Jellicoe Road is a book that you will love. It will make you curious, every thing the main character questions, you will question and you will want to know every answer. The reason why this did not get the 5 stars I really wanted it to give, for me, was the ending. I hate a happy ending. Jellicoe Road was on it's way to 5 stars, but the ending let me down a bit, the last few chapters let me down. It does not take away from the book, but it did make me decide to not give it 5 stars.

This story was amazing. I loved it for all the elements that come together and make one whole cohesive and intricate plot. Taylor's journey to find Hannah, and by extension, her mother, is one that is long and full of obstacles, but it ultimately helps her make peace with her mysterious past.I could not get enough of Narnie, Webb, Tate, Fitz, and Jude. Their story, in its fullness, does everything to enhance Taylor's, and I think it is for this reason that I am giving On the Jellicoe Road 5 stars. Taylor is a strong character who often comes off as cold and indifferent, but underneath that, she is a very sympathetic and likeable person. I give Marchetta huge props for writing such a great protagonist, along with a great cast of side characters.

Things I really liked about this book:- the Australian setting, something a little different from the usual American high school (which always somehow feels like I am reading a teen 'sitcom" and is harder to relate to). I think the hot lazy red earth atmosphere worked really well here as the backdrop for the territory wars.- the writing has an immediacy and urgency that is often lacking in YA fiction. - the slow reveal and unraveling of all the layers, and the family secrets. Although in the beginning it was a bit confusing, the way the two stories unfolded and intersected was cleverly done.- there is something really enjoyable about the tone of this book, the characters and the themes of love and loss and finding yourself.

It is one of my favorite book and just recently I read something similar to it. So, I started reading it again. Again it proved that how good it is in young-adult fiction category.Read the review her : http://www.bookaapi.com/book-review/t...My Blog | Instagram | Facebook | Tumblr | Blogger | Youtube | Twitter

Nu sunt un fan al cărților young adult. Le citesc numai atunci când am nevoie de relaxare și de vreun roi de fluturi. Cartea asta mi-a zdrobit toți fluturii. M-a scuturat, m-a prins zdravăn de gulerul cămășii și m-a luat la trântă. Aparent, este o carte simplă. O poveste despre activitățile de vară ale unor elevi, o competiție care durează de câțiva ani buni, o lecție despre supraviețuire. De parcă mai aveau nevoie de una. Dacă ai răbdare să îi îndepărtezi meticulos straturile, dai peste o carte în care singurătatea, întrebările și teama colcăie.https://ancasicartile.wordpress.com/2...

Contemporary young adult books are not my usual fare, but this book was written so beautifully, that I couldn't help but fall in love with it like everyone else. It's sad & heart-wrenching but at the same time it's touching and sweet. There's heart-ache & loss, but also developing of new friendship & love. This book is just raw & emotional. And yes - it's confusing at the beginning because there are 2 different stories ... or are they different - the author left us to figure out what was happening with a slow unraveling - something that not everyone will like. In fact - I didn't, but I kept reading because of the book's emotional power, and everything that's revealed just blew my mind.

I'm kinda split. On one hand I want to give Jellicoe Road by Melina Marchette 5 stars, but on the other hand the last 200 pages of the books were the only pages, that really caught me and made me want to read more, and more, and more. The book is beautifully written, you care for the characters and it's gracefully pieced together. Yes, it was a bit confusing in the start and the text pieces in italic didn't really make sense until I had read the first half of the book. Then it began to make sense.I enjoyed reading Jellicoe Road, but you have to read and wait patiently to get over with alle the introductions, before the fun and exciting part starts.It still deserves 4 stars, yes.

I've been waiting to read this book for a long time. The reviews drove me to read it, promising something different with plenty of unexpected twists and turns. Sometimes reviews pump books up so much, when I finally get around to reading them, they just don't meet my sky high expectations. I think I would have liked this so much better if I'd not read all the hype beforehand. I should have know, like usual for this type of read, I'd be let down. All that being said, this is a worthwhile read and a great story, just not what I thought it would be. Plus, it probably made it more difficult for me to follow, since I listened to this with "text-to-speech" for the most part, vs reading it.

Trodde jag läste klart den i somras eftersom jag rekommenderat den till vänner, men ja det får en väl göra även om en glömt att en hade 50 sidor kvar. Hur som helst är jag klar nu och jag tycker verkligen om den, särskilt författarens sätt att väva samman två berättelser. Men fastän jag ville veta mer om den dåtida historien och trots att den är hjärtskärande och vacker, kan jag inte låta bli att känna att relationerna i gruppen är lite overkliga på nåt vis, eller lite för poetiska kanske är ett bättre uttryck. Men det är verkligen den enda detalj som finns att störa sig på (men som ändock gör att det inte blir en femma).

You know, I actually almost gave this 3 stars because it's tough to discount the fact that I just couldn't get into this book until over halfway through. I only kept with it thanks to the advice of reviewers and the Printz Award that seemed to promise it would improve. By the end, I loved it, but I do think it could have done with a hefty amount of editorial help in the first half. The characters are excellent, as is the story, and while I understand that Marchetta wanted us to initially feel as confused and perplexed as Taylor, I'm not sure that was really necessary. Still, worth slogging through to the end.

I've read this before but completely forgot. How could I? I love Melina Marchetta and should have bought this book but never did.On the Jellicoe Road is the story of the Territory Wars that happen in Jellicoe between the townies, cadets and boarders at Jellicoe School. Taylor is the new leader but there is talk of a coup instantly. She changes the way the war has run in years and realises what they were all about in the first place.I really loved this book and how Marchetta writes her characters. I think Taylor is my favourite character ever of any of hers. I'd love a sequel... or a prequel for that matter.Definitely a to buy.

This was a beautiful, moving, original and mysterious YA story.I had a hard time with the first half of the book. Reading the two stories was confusing because I was trying to figure out the connection and to keep track of all the characters. I also didn't care for all the focus on the territory wars. Things didn't get interesting until 50%. Then I was hooked. I still have questions about the territory wars. (view spoiler)[Who carried out the territory wars after Webb died? It started out as a game. How did it get so serious? (hide spoiler)] I also want to know more about Raffaela and Chaz's story.
4.8 Brilliant

I think if I'd read this in middle school or junior high, it would've been a favorite that I would revisit multiple times (of course, I was 28 when it was published, so, there's that). The first person narrative, friends as family, and turf wars all reminded me of The Outsiders (which I did read and love in middle school). The improbable number of connections between the characters was Dickensian in scope (but hey, I LOVE Dickens!). I'm glad I listened on audio, because the narrator's Australian accent added a lot to the story.

I had the hardest time getting into this book. In the beginning I was very confused. It took me days to get through the first 150 pages. I really couldn't tell you what happened. I'd heard rumors about Jonah Griggs being the new best book boyfriend (which even by the end I still don't buy..), but I wasn't liking him. Then I read the last 250 pages in one sitting. I just couldn't put it down.I found it pretty predictable about halfway through. But I still enjoyed it. While I thought some of the storytelling/writing was confusing, overall, it was a nice story with a nice message.

Marchetta is rapidly becoming one of my favourite Australian YA authors, both for her more 'gritty/real' books, and her fantasy. This one is liminal, with levels of urban fantasy intertwined throughout. I certainly wouldn't pick it as my favourite of her books - I found it far too traumatising to want to reread it, particularly because the main character really does believe that she is all alone, and can trust no-one to be on her side. I think my favourite line was "...and did you know that Santangelo's black and Italian? Do you know how many cousins he has as a result?"

Be warned and bust out your hanky, because this book was a TEAR JERKER. I agree with what a lot of reviews said about the first half of this book being utterly confusing. I wish the history would have been more of a slow and even reveal but once I understood how the two stories were connected, I immediately began to enjoy the book much more. I could have used less of the 'territory wars' but I suppose we needed a way to get to know everyone. A very well written book indeed, and completely deserving of its Printz medal.

After a slow, confusing start to this book, I must say I feel in love with the story. Its about friendship, love and loss. It was hard trying to figure out the backstory to me, I felt that could have been explained a little better. But after I figured that out, all of it came together for me.I love how you see how friendships change for better or worse and I had a sense at the end that the same was happening with the young people in the book, that they were forming their own story. Loved the ending and I would highly recommend this book!

For the first half of this book I was like, uh ... could you start making some sense please? But the writing was strong enough that I was pretty sure the thread of the story would start to show up sooner or later. Boy am I glad I hung in there. Such a powerful and beautiful story. I loved the relationships between some pretty screwed up/damaged characters: gritty, powerful, and ultimately really moving. And some of the random threads tied together so nicely at the end. Mucho love for this one.

Read my full review on my book blog, Turning Pages.Jellicoe Road is strong novel which focuses on complex relationships between people and reading the story of our past and writing the story of our present. It deals with difficult topics and situations, but does so with a deft hand. The characters and events are riveting and wonderful and complex.

I loved this book and would have given it 5 stars except that it didn't fully grab me until about 100 pages in. Initially, I was completely confused, and disinterested in the territory wars, but finally the pieces began falling into place and I raced through the second half. Marchetta has a knack for dialogue and showing intense emotion, and I loved how the dual narratives ultimately came together with healing and hope.

Tragedy, friendship, loss, love, growing up.Parallel lives, intertwined relationships. This book has two storylines - something that takes some time to tease out, with timelines a bit confusing until you start to follow the threads. But its well worth staying with the book - the last third really pulls plotlines together and our MC (Taylor Markham) grows and becomes a much better person. The other current day MCs are great, finding their place in the world and shining.

Realized I never wrote about my love for this book. This is one of those great, meaty Y.A.s that you can shove at any person who sniffs that they only read "adult books." The protagonists might be teenaged, but the story is multi-layered, intriguing, and almost overworldly. Melina Marchetta obviously took a good deal of time plotting this book, and the writing shows.And Jonah Griggs, of course, is swoonable and up there with Marcus Flutie for perfect love interests.

This author is becoming a favorite perhaps because of my cute Austrailian neighbor! I found all of the characters endearing in their own way. I really liked how the author gave you Taylor's perspective of the other characters and then you gradually get a better picture with the other's perspectives and with Taylor realizing how much she cares for them as a family. I also liked the story within a story that gave this book a mystery of how the two connect. Great read!

Magnificent. Marchetta is an exciting writer and I thoroughly enjoyed her prose and by the end, did not want to put the book down. It does take a while to get into it- the first person narrator doesn't give much away and so the first 100 pages I was wondering just what was happening and if everything we were being 'told' was real or the narrator's perception.

If I could seperate my review by rating the first half and then the second half, I would give the first half a 1 and the second a 5. I didnt see the point in confusing the reader so much in the beginning and it made me put down the book several times out of annoyance. However, it has such good reviews that I soldiered through and really enjoyed the second half.

A beautiful book. I was pulled into the setting, the characters, the simultaneous unfolding of two lovely and heartbreaking stories. Almost 5 stars, but the beginning was so confusing. One of those books where you get thrown into the middle of a story without much explanation or background. Left me floundering for a bit. BUT once I committed and got past the first 50-ish pages I was hooked.

I was incredibly sucked in to this book and reluctant to let go when it came to an end. It was almost a five star for me but at times I felt as if there were too many characters to keep track of and it took away from the story a little. Still a really good coming of age story and definitely a story that redefines family and reminds you that not everything is as it seems.

Åh, hvor var den gode jeg kunne rigtig godt lide selve historien. Jeg synes ikke alle plot-twistene var overraskende, men det gjorde sådan set heller ikke noget, de gjorde alligevel historien spændende. Jeg kunne rigtig godt lide den måde vi får fortalt historien og personerne var utrolig interessante af følge.

It took me a little while to get into this one and really understand what was going on, but by then end I was so in love with the characters and their stories. Really something special here. I very much suspect that if I go back and read it a second time I'll have to give it five starts. Mark my words, it'll happen.

This one was a bit confusing early on. To be honest, if I hadn't heard so many good things about it I might not have kept going. But I'm very glad I did. Everything came together over the course of the story. The characters were well done and I loved the chemistry between Taylor and Jonah. A fascinating story.

I definitely think On the Jellicoe Road needs to be experienced first hand. There aren't many of the right words to appreciate it and explain how you feel while reading it. Now having read two of her works, I completely understand why Melina's contribution to YA Literature is so highly praised.

I read Jellicoe Road in a single day — something I haven’t done in ages. It’s a powerful coming of age story about friendship and rivalry between different groups in a small community. It also has a mystery that tugs at the past, bringing secrets to light. There’s a lot of humor and a lot of tragedy and it all weaves together beautifully.

This book definitely deserves its accolades. The story is beautiful and not what I expected. I was overly frustrated by the structure of the novel, but I might argue that the author would welcome my frustration as a part of Taylor's emotional challenges. I recommend this book to those who like realistic fiction and mysteries.
